Author: Emmy Sobieski CFA
Post Text: Stop taking notes during meetings. Seriously. üìù‚ùåAt first, like any good analyst, I took notes. I wanted to remember everything that was said.But as we walked out of a meeting one day, my previous boss told me, "You‚Äôre smart enough to remember what was said for thirty minutes. Don't take notes."Here's why you should ditch the notepad and embrace a new approach:In today's fast-paced business world, it's common for professionals to enter meetings armed with notepads or laptops, ready to jot down every detail of the conversation.However, my old boss challenged this approach by encouraging his analysts to stop taking notes during meetings. Instead, he recommends retaining information mentally and jotting down key points after leaving the room.Why should you adopt this unconventional method?The idea is that taking notes during meetings can make others feel guarded and less open to sharing valuable information. By refraining from writing down every word, you can maintain eye contact and focus on the speaker, making them feel important and heard. This subtle shift can lead to richer, more insightful conversations and ultimately, better networking experiences.Another critical aspect of networking is mastering the art of conversation.To become a better conversationalist, ask open-ended, neutral questions followed by relevant follow-ups. This hopscotch method allows you to delve deeper into a topic without making the other person feel uncomfortable or pressured to overshare. Remember, the key to successful networking is to talk less, ask more, and listen intently.#careers #entrepreneurship #venturecapital

Author: Emmy Sobieski CFA
Post Text: Your career, like your life, has phases. I call them the 3Ô∏è‚É£ B‚Äôs:üéØBreak InüéØBuild EquityüéØBreak Out1Ô∏è‚É£Break In:Get a job in investment banking, management consulting, or investing.You need to know the path and options early enough to get the grades, to be able to break into investment banking (IB) or management consulting. You can break in later by working at a great startup or getting an MBA and then a job in IB or consulting.‚Äã2Ô∏è‚É£ Build EquityGet paid for performance, not based on your salary, but based on the inherent leverage in the business. When managing money (PE/VC/Hedge Fund), equity comes in the form of being paid in carry, ie your share of profits of the funds run by you and/or the firm. In startups, building equity separates your time from money earned.In the Building Equity phase of your career, you build multiple paths of wealth generation. You earn equity in your full time job. You can invest in other companies. You can scout for a VC firm. You can be on company boards.If you think this sounds far-fetched, two of my friends who hit $100M by age 50 from diverse backgrounds both live the above model (running companies, on boards, working with VCs).To make $100M, you need to build equity. You don‚Äôt necessarily need to go further. Bill Gurley started as an engineer at Compaq computer, transitioned to an analyst on Wall Street, moved from analyzing computer stocks to internet platforms (by switching jobs), took Amazon public, got a partner role at Benchmark (a VC firm), focusing on internet platforms, invested in Uber, and is worth billions.3Ô∏è‚É£Break OutBuild your own firm, either a startup or asset management company.The very wealthiest in the world all Broke Out. Elon Musk. Bill Gates. Warren Buffet. Sarah Blakely. Founders whose startups grew to some of the most valuable companies in the world.Breaking Out is also the most risky, and the most littered with lost fortunes.If your goal is $100M or even a billion dollar career, your path may not need to take on the risk of entering the Breaking Out phase. The key is knowing yourself and your options. Pick the best path for you.My book, $100M Careers, helps you build that path.#careers #venturecapital #entrepenurship

Author: Emmy Sobieski CFA
Post Text: Why You Don‚Äôt Have to Be First: The Second-Mover AdvantageBrand-new industries can take a long time to emerge. Long enough for you to run out of money before you find the one you‚Äôre looking for.How do these first movers get it right? IBM was producing software before Microsoft. Bill Gates just separated the hardware from the software. Then he got IBM to let Microsoft make software for IBM and resell it to others. He launched the entire PC industry through the wording of one contract! Microsoft focused on operating systems, word processing, and spreadsheets. WordStar also made word processors, but Microsoft bundled its software with its real asset, the operating system. IBM had allowed them to sell to others even though it was built at the request of IBM.Gates was late enough to see how it had been done wrong. And early enough to provide significant improvements to customers and grab an entire industry.Before Oracle, databases were all built by IBM and Wang. And they were an afterthought at Microsoft. Oracle went on to own that market.Gates and Elison started back in the 1970s. What about the future?The Internet‚Äôs scale and network effects make being early crucial. Take Marc Andreesen. Born in 1971, Marc created the Mosaic browser (Netscape) as a computer science student. Today he‚Äôs one of the most powerful venture capitalists.But even the Internet is full of second movers.As websites multiplied faster than rabbits, finding what you're looking for became difficult. Most systems like Yahoo used human indexers and editors. But Google used the power of math running on cheap, networked computers to rank pages and predict the answers users most wanted.Google is an example of second-mover advantage. They were early enough to have tons of growth ahead, but late enough to learn from others‚Äô mistakes. Facebook, now Meta, is another example. The company arrived after MySpace and Friendster.  Founder Mark Zuckerberg saw what didn‚Äôt work and what did.The trick is getting in early enough to capture most of the gains while being able to learn from others‚Äô failures. And the Internet‚Äôs network effects mean that the upward curve of progress in users, sales, and profits is geometric. That makes it far harder to catch the leaders once they have product-market fit.#entrepreneurship #startups #careers

Author: Emmy Sobieski CFA
Post Text: Why You Don‚Äôt Have to Be First: The Second-Mover AdvantageBrand-new industries can take a long time to emerge. Long enough for you to run out of money before you find the one you‚Äôre looking for.How do these first movers get it right? IBM was producing software before Microsoft. Bill Gates just separated the hardware from the software. Then he got IBM to let Microsoft make software for IBM and resell it to others. He launched the entire PC industry through the wording of one contract! Keep in mind, Bill Gates‚Äô dad was a contract lawyer. Microsoft focused on operating systems, word processing, and spreadsheets. WordStar also made word processors, but Microsoft bundled its software with its real asset, the operating system. Which IBM had allowed them to sell to others even though it was built at the request of IBM.Gates was late enough to see how it had been done wrong. And early enough to provide significant improvements to customers and grab an entire industry.Before Oracle, databases were all built by IBM and Wang. And they were an afterthought at Microsoft. Oracle went on to own that market.Gates and Elison started back in the 1970s. What about the future?The Internet‚Äôs scale and network effects make being early crucial. Take Marc Andreesen. Born in 1971, Marc created the Mosaic browser (Netscape) as a computer science student. Today he‚Äôs one of the most powerful venture capitalists.But even the Internet is full of second movers.As websites multiplied faster than rabbits, it became difficult to find what you're looking for. Most systems like Yahoo used human indexers and editors. But Google used the power of math running on cheap, networked computers to rank pages and predict the answers users most wanted.Google is an example of second-mover advantage. They were early enough to have tons of growth ahead, but late enough to learn from others‚Äô mistakes. Facebook, now Meta, is another example. The company arrived after MySpace and Friendster.  Founder Mark Zuckerberg saw what didn‚Äôt work and what did.The trick is getting in early enough to capture most of the gains while being able to learn from others‚Äô failures. And the Internet‚Äôs network effects mean that the upward curve of progress in users, sales, and profits is geometric. That makes it far harder to catch the leaders once they have product-market fit. #entrepreneurship #investing #startups

Author: Emmy Sobieski CFA
Post Text: Private Equity vs Venture Capital for your $100M CareerPrivate Equity is a lot like Venture Capital. Private Equity firms tend to invest side by side with late-stage venture capital firms.Which do you do?Those who thrive in Private Equity love the mathematical side of things. They love modeling and they‚Äôre more risk averse, preferring to model out business decisions.My most successful mentee in PE loved modeling, creating regressions, and being pulled in on important deals. At the same time, he doesn‚Äôt like a lot of uncertainty. Picking a stock, thinking about the future, and considering the possibilities of what might happen are not interesting to him. But, looking at how he can structure super complex deals is fascinating to him. He enjoys getting rid of almost all the risk and creating a whole bunch of upside (the asymmetric trade).People like that flourish in private equity.Venture Capitalists spend lots of time in deep thought on where the future is headed. From this thought and research, they build a thesis or a way they can invest around that future. Then, they figure out how to deploy capital using the thesis.The firms that invest in seed and Series A and Series B, they‚Äôre very different from PE. As a VC, you‚Äôre imagining how the team might change the future with their innovation. You're envisioning how that might fit with one of your themes or theses for how the future will play out. There‚Äôs not much financial modeling.As a VC, you‚Äôre going to wade through a ton of pitch decks. Some will be passed on to you. Some will be sent in. Some pitch decks you‚Äôll solicit. Then you‚Äôll decide which founders you want to meet with. You‚Äôll be chasing hot deals and trying to avoid the dogs while picking out diamonds in the rough.You‚Äôll also be spending huge amounts of time networking with groups of founders and board directors. Because they can give you access to the best and hottest deals.For a deeper dive into Private Equity or Venture Capital career paths, check out my book $100M Careers: The 5 FASTEST Career Paths to Wealth Beyond Your Wildest Dreams.#venturecapital #investing #careers

Post Text: Did you know that MICRO-MOMENTS can make a lifetime impact in just minutes? ü§ØWe often rush through our day, missing out on these precious opportunities to connect. Post Text: Hedge funds: once a playground for the wealthy, now an institutionalized asset class.But as fees attracted more talent, not all were up to the task.Discover how hedge funds have evolved and where they stand today in the financial landscape.üëáThe Origin Story of Hedge Funds began with wealthy individuals seeking market upside without downside exposure. They paid for net performance, or "Alpha," with the famous two and twenty fee structure (2% of Assets Under Management and 20% of returns). This aimed to align clients with hedge fund managers, focusing on absolute returns in any market.However, the problem with hedge funds is that a poor manager can lose money both ways. Two things happened as a result: talent dilution and client institutionalization.Talent dilution occurred as the attractive fees brought in managers who didn't know what they were doing, leading to losses on both shorts and longs. This drove the emergence of leveraged long strategies like 120/20 and 130/30 in the late 1990s.Client institutionalization shifted hedge funds from being solely for the rich to an asset class for institutions like college endowments. This led to the implementation of risk management practices, transforming the hedge fund landscape and spawning firms like Citadel, which perfected Reversion to the Mean and Pairs trading.The Market Neutral strategy emerged, going long and short on two similar names to minimize tracking error. Citadel could run billions of dollars in this manner, charging two and twenty while reducing volatility.Today, multiple hedge fund strategies exist, catering to various investor needs. Though the market share of hedge funds is decreasing, opportunities can still be found as long as one is aware of the challenges.#investing #venturecapital #careers

XYZ is poised to be the leader in connecting small businesses to crypto payments.Delivering great stock pitches was the key to me winning EVERY job offer in my career, each time over candidates with better resumes. Author: Emmy Sobieski CFA
Post Text: Old Money, New Rules: The Hedge Fund CareerToday, there are multiple hedge fund strategies for this high-leveraged career:1. Short Only: This involves hunting down overvalued stocks, and often snooping around to find trouble signs ignored by other investors; if they can find accounting fraud or another type of malfeasance, they can earn big!2. Quantitative: This is all about using a lot of statistical models, called Quantitative Analysis, or QA. They often use technology to make trades based on these mathematical models, or even implement machine learning. 3. Event-Driven: This focuses on buying the debt of companies in financial distress, as that can yield high potential returns. 4. Global Macro: This is all about examining the global macroeconomic trends, focusing on how they will impact interest rates, currencies, commodities, or equities all across the globe.5. Merger Arbitrage: This is all about deriving returns from takeovers. Takeovers are subject to a lot of conditions, like regulatory approval and a favorable vote by the target company‚Äôs shareholders, so funds bet whether or not the mergers will get done.6. Convertible Arbitrage: This is all about thriving on volatility, focusing on trading convertibles, a type of hybrid bond.7. Fixed Income Arbitrage: This focuses on eliminating credit risk by focusing on risk-free government bonds, buying them in one market and selling them in another. 8. Market Neutral: This is all about trying to get zero net-market exposure, where shorts and longs have equal market value.9. Credit: This is focusing on credit rather than interest rates, trading in complex structured debt vehicles.10. Equity Long/Short: This is the classic, the old school; bet on the expected winners with long positions, and bet on the expected losers with short.11. Multi-Strat: Funds like Millenium have many types of managers with different strategies chosen from the above menu of 10 strategies as well as ones I haven‚Äôt listed. It‚Äôs a one-stop-shop for clients who can move money between managers while keeping it in the firm. This segment has grown rapidly as assets are more sticky for the hedge fund company while institutional investors have more choice. Research the areas that you‚Äôd like to be in. But keep in mind, hedge funds are a smaller percentage of institutional investors‚Äô overall allocation, as they have invested more in passive long-only strategies, as well as VC and PE funds during long bull markets.Though the market share of hedge funds is decreasing, opportunities can still be found as long as one is aware of the challenges. üìà#investing #careers #venturecapital

Post Text: Mastering micro-moments can skyrocket your career and personal relationships üöÄWe often underestimate the power of focused connection and deep listening.Here's how these skills can make all the difference: ‚¨áÔ∏èIn today's fast-paced world, it's easy to get caught up in our own thoughts and ambitions. To truly excel, one must learn to incorporate advanced micro-moment skills into their interactions.ü§îFirst, learn to use specific asks. Instead of asking a vague question like, "Who do you know who could help me?", try being more precise. For example, "I noticed you worked with Joe at your last firm. This approach demonstrates that you've done your research and value the person's time and connections.‚åõSecond, practice time blocking. When engaging someone, always mention how much of their time you'll take and stick to it. Though it may be tempting to extend the conversation if they seem relaxed, respecting their time demonstrates professionalism and leaves a positive impression.üíéLastly, believe that you can give value. Even as a college student or someone early in their career, you can offer value to seasoned professionals by understanding their pain points and offering creative solutions. The benefits extend beyond your professional life‚Ä¶By genuinely listening and focusing on others during interactions, you'll forge stronger personal connections with family and friends.
